title: What was the last good decade for music, and why is that? - Quora

response.answer_text: My knee jerk response here is to give this question serious thought, and my response would be the 90s. You had Nirvana, Sublime, the Wu Tang Clan, (you had Old Dirty Bastard of the Wu Tang Clan, the most original and incredible rapper of all time), and because of them and others like them, the 90s were the last good decade for music. The 90s certainly weren’t the best decade for good music, but they were the last. Not just in my opinion either; that’s a hard fact. WARNING: VIDEO BELOW IS EXPLICIT (in the best kind of way)  (Are you gonna argue with this guy?) But when I slow down a bit, when I stop, I clearly see the trap that’s been laid out for me … and I’m not gonna fall in it today. Not today! Because what you’re really asking me, good sir or madam, is simply this: “how old are you?” One thing I’ve learned along the way about music is that we all love what we grew up listening to more than all the other shit that’s out there. If you grew up in the 60s and 70s you’ll be grooving to classic rock like The Who, Zeppelin, the Beatles, Dillon, or perhaps, God help us all, the Bee Gees, and as for everything else, it’s just not “far out” in the way your music is. If you grew up in the 30s and 40s, you’ll probably be doing the Jitterbug to some Bing Crosby, Benny Goodman, or Glenn Miller, and the junk the kids listen to is basically sacrilegious. Did you see the way he shook his hips!?! It’s a cultural trend that’s stuck on repeat, generation after generation it stays pretty much the same, although it does feel like the rules are getting looser as we go. Let me explain: Young people listen to their music, and then they get older and they still listen to their music. They may listen to newer stuff, and they may even love some of it, but it will never be as good as their music; the music of their youth. And mostly they won’t understand the new music. They just won’t get it. And then they’ll have kids of their own, and they’ll think to themselves “this is what they like? This trash? It’s literally the worst shit I’ve ever heard!”, and they will shake their heads in bewilderment. And their kids will listen to their newfangled music. And then they’ll get older and they’ll still listen to their music. And then they have kids, and the circle continues, ad infinitum. But like I eluded to above, it seems like these days parents are staying “young and hip” a lot longer than before. Please notice I’ve put “young and hip” in quotes, because they (we) are actually neither of those things. And I can say that because I am one hundred percent one of those parents.  So the real answer to your question is, of course, that there is still good music and there will always be good music. It’s just your taste that, with the flow of time, has become lame and outdated. Admittedly though, you have to look a lot harder for the good stuff these days because there’s just so much music out there. We’re oversaturated for sure, and it makes it harder to find what you really love. Unless of course you’re into auto-tuned, talentless music with zero instruments, words you can’t understand and would be disappointed if you could, and the same three songs being repeated over and over. If that’s what you’re looking for, just look around you cause that’s what’s hot these days! Sorry, had to get that last bit in. I’m old and bitter, after all.

The 70s. Not all the digital crap, things were new…sounds and styles. Now they’re just repeats and remakes. Pop music today in whiny. And it follows formulas. I’m a jazz and blues guy. Jazz and blues is pretty traditional and there are some very fine young jazz / blues musicians out and about. But they have a tough row to hoe. The dudes in those record company ivory towers want commercial, commercial, commercial…Back in the day they wanted music and innovation.
